ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Laser-induced voltage (LIV) enhancement of La2/3Sr1/3MnO3 films with Ag addition

Affiliation.OrgDivision: Faculty of Material Science and Engineering
Affiliation.OrgName: Kunming University of Science and Technology

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para:
La2/3Sr1/3MnO3:Ag x (LSMO:Ag x , x=0, 0.04, 0.08, 0.10, 0.20, 0.30) films were grown on vicinal cut LaAlO3 (LAO) substrates by pulsed laser deposition technique (PLD). It is found that laser-induced voltage (LIV) of LSMO:Ag x films is improved and enhanced by Ag addition. With x increasing, figure of merit (F
m ) and anisotropic Seebeck coefficient (ΔS) of LSMO:Ag x (x=0.08) films reach the maximum values of 28.25 mV/ns and 0.38 μV/K, respectively. The results suggest that the LIV enhancement of LSMO:Ag x films is due to the anisotropy of the Seebeck tensor, which is produced by long range cooperative Jahn–Teller distortions with Ag addition.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para:
The experiment of laser-induced voltage (LIV) effect, in which the YBa2Cu3O7−δ films were used as a photosensor, was performed first by Chang et al. [1]. This discovery extends the field of devices application and also provides new insight for understanding the subject of strong-correlated electrons [2, 3]. The LIV is dominated by the anisotropy of thermo-electric power and is associated with the thermal properties as well as the self-organized structure of the tilted films [4–12]. An atomic layer thermopile (ALT) model based on the existence of off-diagonal elements of the anisotropic Seebeck coefficient (ΔS) was proposed to explain the LIV effect [13, 14]. The anisotropy of the Seebeck tensor was due to long range cooperative Jahn–Teller distortions [15]. Furthermore, a series of Ag-doped La0.6Pb0.4MnO3 (LPMO) thin films grown on vicinal cut substrates were investigated and anisotropic Seebeck enhancement with optimum Ag addition was discussed [16]. Manganites with doped Ag show significantly enhanced electrical and magnetic transport properties by increasing the amount of Mn4+ through Ag-ion substitution [17, 18]. Obviously, initial small LIV signals can be enhanced by ions in substitution or changing the doping level as well as the lattice mismatch between the substrates and the films. In this direction, we were looking for improvement of the LIV of LSMO films with the addition of Ag. Searching for optimal Ag addition to LSMO films with high LIV sensitivity, as well as the fast response time, namely the high figure of merit (F
m ) value of the thermo-electric devices, is the purpose of this work. Consequently, the performance and the F
m value of the LIV devices were improved substantially by the Ag addition.

Section1.Heading: Experimental
Section1.Para: LSMO:Ag x ceramic disks (x=0, 0.04, 0.08, 0.10, 0.20, 0.30) used as the targets in the PLD experiments were synthesized by co-precipitation method [19]. The substrate was LAO single crystal with 15° tilting angle to the c-axis. PLD experiments were performed by using a KrF excimer-laser of 248-nm wavelength (λ) and 20 ns pulse width. Optimized laser fluency of 1.6 J/cm2 and repetition rate of 5 Hz was utilized. During the deposition procedure, the substrate temperature and the pressure of flowing oxygen pressure were precisely kept at 790 °C and 45 Pa, respectively. The deposition time and the thickness of the film were 5 min and around 250 nm, respectively, which was the optimal thickness of La2/3Ca1/3MnO3 (LCMO) [20] and YBa2Cu3O7−δ (YBCO) [21] films to produce large LIV effect. Then all the samples were annealed in situ at 760 °C in an oxygen under pressure of 104 Pa for 30 min. Finally, the samples were cooled to room temperature at a cooling rate of 10 °C /min. The structure and phase purity of the LCMO: Ag x composites were analysed by powder X-ray diffraction (XRD). The atomic force microscope (AFM) images were obtained by SHIMADZU SPM-9600. LIV signals were detected by oscilloscope (Tektronix TD210) with the input impedance of 1 MΩ.

Section1.Heading: Results and discussion
Section1.Para:
Figure 1 shows the XRD patterns of the LSMO:Ag x films deposited on tilted 15° LAO substrates. All of curves show that besides the peaks of the substrate, only the LSMO film (00l) peaks are present, which indicates all the films are grown on high quality substrates and the (00l) orientation along with the LAO (00l) substrates. Compared with the pure film, the (001) and (002) peak of other films with the Ag addition shift to the low angle gradually, which suggests that Ag addition causes the lattice distortion. Ye et al. pointed out that doping with Ag will lead a small amount of Ag ions into the lattice, replacing La and Sr ions [15]. Since the ionic radius of Ag+ (1.28 Å) is larger than that of La3+ (1.16 Å) and Sr2+ (1.26 Å), the substitution will cause the lattice to expand slightly. For this reason, the bond length of Mn–O becomes shorter and the bond angle of Mn–O–Mn becomes larger, which can enhance the double exchange interaction between Mn3+ and Mn4+. Tilting of Mn–O bond directly affects the electron hopping amplitude from one Mn site to another Mn site, leading to large anisotropy of the conductivity as well as the Seebeck coefficient.
Fig. 1
XRD patterns of LSMO:Ag x films. The ‘∗’ is corresponding to the k
β

Figure 2 presents the AFM images of LSMO:Ag x films (with x=0, 0.08, 0.20). The average roughness (Ra) of the films (x=0, 0.08 and 0.20) is 4.867, 5.480 and 4.071 nm, respectively. The surface of the film with x=0.08 is rougher than the films with x=0 and x=0.20, which indicates that the inhomogeneity of the films improves the ΔS. From the AFM results and formula (1) which will be discussed later, it can be ensured that the peak value of LIV (U
p ) will be enhanced by the ΔS factor.
Fig. 2
AFM images of LSMO:Ag x films: (a) (d) x=0, (b) (e) x=0.08, (c) (f) x=0.2

Figure 3 shows the dependence of time on LIV signals obtained from the LSMO films with various Ag additions. Meanwhile, Table 1 shows the measured values of LIV signals. Here we defined the figure of merit F
m =U
p /τ, where U
p is the peak value of the LIV and τ is response time (from 0 to U
p ) of LIV signals [22]. It is found that U
p , F
m and ΔS are improved by doping Ag in LSMO films except for the x=0.30 sample. With x=0.08, the U
p , F
m and ΔS are reaching maximum values of 1104.26 mV, 28.25 mV/ns and 0.38 μV/K, respectively. However, increasing the Ag addition above 0.08, the U
p , F
m and ΔS instead decrease. Notably, these results are ascribed to the changes of the anisotropic Seebeck coefficient matrix components upon Ag addition [6]. It is also evident that F
m and ΔS values can be enhanced by optimizing the Ag addition in LSMO films.

In order to correlate the material parameters to the induced voltage and the device performance, H. Lengfellner et al. described the phenomenon quantitatively by deriving a formula based on the anisotropic thermo-electric model [13]:
1
$$ U = \frac{l}{2}\Delta S\nabla_{Z}T\sin2\theta $$ where l is the length of illumination, ΔS=|S
ab −S
c | is the anisotropic Seebeck coefficient with the value of difference between S
ab (Seebeck coefficient in ab-plane) and S
c (Seebeck coefficient along c-axis), ∇ Z
T is the temperature gradient between film surface and film bottom, and θ is the tilted angle of the film c-axis. From the heat flow equation [23] Q=κ∇ Z
T=E pulse/τ, where Q is the heat current density, the temperature gradient ∇ Z
T can be estimated. E pulse is the absorbed laser fluence, E pulse=0.45 mJ/mm2, τ is the response time (from 0 to U
p ) and κ=1 W/m⋅K is the thermal heat conductivity [24]; l is 1 mm, θ is 15°. Using these values, the ∇ Z
T and ΔS can be calculated, as shown in Table 1. This method proved effective to acquire the anisotropic Seebeck coefficient [14, 25, 26]. The ΔS is improved at first with Ag addition increasing, reaching the maximum at x=0.08 and then decreasing, which is in accordance with the result of Ra. Meanwhile, the change of U
p and F
m is the same as ΔS, which also suggests that the LIV is induced by the anisotropic Seebeck effect. The optimal Ag addition level is beneficial to enhance the anisotropic Seebeck coefficient (ΔS) and the LIV effect of LSMO films.

With the Ag addition the manganite formula can be written as
$\mathrm{La}_{1 -x}^{3 +} \mathrm{Sr}_{x - y}^{2 +} \mathrm{Ag}_{y}^{1 +} \mathrm{Mn}_{1 - (x + y)}^{3 +} \mathrm{Mn}_{x + y}^{4+}\mathrm{O}_{3}^{2 -}$ for a small amount of substitution. With Ag1+ increasing, more Mn4+ is produced, which results in a high density of carriers; hence a high electrical conductivity and an enhanced double exchange interaction. However, over-doping of Ag1+ leads to a reduction of Mn3+–O–Mn4+ pairs, which will suppress the double exchange. In photo-electron process, electrons and holes are created by photons, and then the thermal gradient causes the movement of the carriers, resulting in the voltage in the system. Therefore, after reaching the maximum, the ΔS and F
m are reduced. This is in agreement with the experimental results: the F
m value of the films increases with the small Ag addition, and after reaching the maximum then reduces with the further doping.

Section1.Heading: Conclusion
Section1.Para:
In summary, we have prepared La2/3Sr1/3MnO3:Ag x films on vicinal cut LAO substrates with various Ag additions by PLD. All the films have a perovskite-type structure and show the (00l) orientation along with the LAO (00l) substrates. Doping with Ag has been demonstrated to be an effective way of improving the performance (F
m ) of ALT devices. Optimizing Ag addition with x=0.08 will induce large ΔS and F
m , which means the LIV of LSMO:Ag x films could be enhanced accordingly. The LIV enhancement of LSMO:Ag x films is proved to be resulting from the anisotropic thermo-electric effect.
